title: 112_hr2730
content: The Act titled "Strengthening the Child Welfare Response to Human Trafficking Act of 2011" aims to improve local efforts to combat trafficking and sexual exploitation. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will develop guidelines for training child welfare and court employees in identifying and supporting children at risk of trafficking. Additionally, a toolkit of best practices will be created. Services will develop guidelines for State child welfare agencies to prevent child trafficking, including collaboration with law enforcement and non-profits. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will use research and input from relevant agencies to create a best practices toolkit. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide support to monitor and evaluate programs at State and county agencies related to human trafficking. Recommendations will be drafted for State child welfare agencies to update licensing requirements for specialized residential facilities serving trafficking victims. Data collection and reporting will be streamlined. Streamlining data collection and reporting for child welfare services to classify and identify child trafficking victims. The data collection system for child welfare services includes reporting missing or abducted children to law enforcement. Documentation of specialized services for child trafficking victims is required. The legislation requires documentation of safety measures and services for trafficked children in foster care, extending services for trafficked youth up to age 21. Former foster care recipients who are victims of trafficking can access services until the child turns 21. The effective date for this section and its amendments is January 1, 2012, with a delay permitted if state legislation is required. The State plan is not considered non-compliant with requirements solely based on not meeting additional requirements before a specified deadline. For states with a 2-year legislative session, each year is considered a separate session. SEC. 3. Child welfare agencies must provide services to prevent human trafficking of children and help child victims of trafficking. Child welfare agencies are required to describe their practices and future plans regarding human trafficking and commercial sexual exploitation of children by January 1, 2013. This includes collaborations with local and State agencies and nonprofit organizations to identify and care for children at risk of becoming victims of human trafficking. Child welfare agencies must provide training, address jurisdictional limits, collect data on child trafficking victims, and educate families and at-risk children on human trafficking and exploitation by January 1, 2013.
